body.p:
To His Excellency
Beriah Magoffin Governor of Kentucky,

Your Petitioners beg leave to state that we have been informed that James A Ransom, a convict in the Ky Penitentiary, sent from Covington is quite ill, unable to work that he has been some time in the Hospital --

We refer your Excellency to a Petition now in your hands for the facts as to Ransoms offense -- trial and conviction, His widowed mother is in deep distress, and poverty, and now deprived of almost her only support by the confinement of James, is in danger of extreme suffering from the cold of the coming Winter, We ask that you will give this case an immediate examination and if compatible with reason, justice, humanity and the welfare of society, that you will grant him an immediate pardon. Covington Ky Oct 31/60

Names
John McDonald
A C. Ellis
Peter Longhorse
James Mcferson
Jacob Metz

Marshal of Covington, if consistant with your Feeling, and believing that he has already Sufferd greately in flesh, he may and I hope will reform and restore happeniness to his afflicted ^mother^ and aid him in his good Intention of reforming. I have given my Name to his pettishier

Covington Nov 10th, I was present & when James Ransom was tried & hardly thought a conviction could be found under the testimony offered. I perceive the names of several lawyers attached to this petition & suppose that they were impressed similarly to myself. John M. Casey

H, Myers
John Ben
I am satisfied the statement in the above petition are strictly true. the original petition gives the facts. I am satisfied that this is a proper subject for the interferance of Executive clemency & hope if the young man is released he will soon be able to aid his poor mother, as he has certainly ever been an industrious boy --
I fully concur with the above
